item.title: Support for S3-class cloud storage
item.description: For relatively obvious reasons, we are working towards supporting teams and groups who wish to contribute to a single, collective repository of archived material. The first step in this direction is to open up the data storage options, so archived records can be browsed by several people. We‚Äôve just released the Toolkit v.0.11.0 which now supports S3-class cloud storage as both a destination and a source ‚Äì in plain English, the Toolkit can now replicate its archives to the cloud and serve data from it.

item.title: End of grant announcement: the Toolkit is now MVP!
item.description: The DEPToolkit is a proof-of-concept software for researchers and small teams sifting through online material. With only one click of the mouse, the material will be archived in a framework demonstrating chain of custody and stored durably. Once included in the growing database, users will be able to go back to search through and annotate the material, and to export working copies of said material for publication and dissemination. A database built thusly can be handed to a prosecutor ten years down the line, and they will be able to say with mathematical certainty: ‚Äúthe material in this archive is identical and contemporary to the one saved at the time, ten years ago.

item.title: Addressing the Berkeley protocol
item.description: The leading light in terms of what we're shooting for is the Berkeley Protocol on Digital Open Source Investigations. The Protocol defines an adequate preservation as respecting certain criteria. Here's how the Digital Evidence Toolkit follows these guidelines: Authenticity "A digital item remains unchanged from when it was collected" The Toolkit preserves content and authenticity proofs (SHA256 hashes of all files and bundles, a U.S. federal standard) separately and implements both the verification of an item and the lookup of a collection of items in the archive.

item.title: Newsletter #4: Time(stamped), Time(lapsed)
item.description: Time. Dates. Data points in the legal battle over the value of pieces of evidence. But are they really this hard, indisputable and demonstrable? Metadata is supposed to describe a digital medium ‚Äì¬†the word comes from meta: ‚Äúreferring to itself, or to something of its own type,‚Äù reads the Cambridge Dictionary. Think of the date at which a picture was taken, the model of scanner used to digitise a piece of paper, a location somewhere on the planet added by the uploader of a video, as well as its description…

item.title: Newsletter #3: Our idea to preserve digital evidence
item.description: _(In case you missed it last week, the previous issue of this newsletter, ‚ÄúWait, digital evidence?‚Äù in which we touch on chain of custody and admissibility, can be found here)__ It’s maybe time to clarify a few things about what the Digital Evidence Preservation Toolkit is and does*, from the two original thoughts: Content living online is at risk. Deletion, link rot, censorship, accidental destruction ‚Äì you name it. The social internet may be great at surfacing and disseminating information but it’s pretty terrible at preserving it.

item.title: Newsletter #2: Wait, digital evidence?
item.description: A brief intro to its unclear evidentiary value and admissibility before the courts It would be difficult to explain our ambitions for the Digital Evidence Toolkit without first defining ‚Äòdigital evidence,‚Äô a term used to describe any information stored in a digital format that is related to any future or ongoing litigation. This evidence may be stored on physical devices (such as smartphones, computers, or hard drives), or transmitted on the internet.

item.title: Newsletter #1: What is the ‚ÄúDigital Evidence Toolkit‚Äù and how can you become involved?
item.description: A new threat looms over international prosecutions ‚Äì I’d love your help What if digital evidence collected over a period of years, or even decades, wasn’t admissible within court because it was improperly’ handled by individuals with nothing but the best intentions? In the complete absence of internationally recognised legal standards regarding how digital forms of evidence should be recorded, handled, and archived - future prosecution efforts continue to remain in jeopardy.
